In caves in the US, female bats help unrelated fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right birthing position. Some people might say that they are being caring. Fifty years ago, people thought that animals didn’t have consciousness, feelings or moral systems. But recently that has changed. Thanks to research into the behaviour of bats, chimps, not to mention rats, dolphins and chickens, we now know that animals have emotions. It is a change that has in recent years filtered through the scientific strata to a selection of popular science books. And it has started a debate that may never be solved by science: can animals be said to have consciousness?

The debate about animal consciousness raises a second question: conscience – a person’s moral sense of right and wrong that guides their behaviour. In a recent experiment involving cows that had to open a locked gate in order to get food, it became apparent that those that successfully opened the gate themselves showed more pleasure than those that had to have the gate opened for them. If, as this research seems to imply, cows enjoy problem-solving, what does it mean for the production and consumption of beef? The observations may not be disputed, but the interpretation of them is. Some people believe that the only logically consistent response to the new research is to stop eating meat. Others believe that we should at the very least re-evaluate our view of animal cognition.
